sections.content: Zero-runtimeStylesheets-in-TypeScript.  Write your styles in TypeScript (or JavaScript) with locally scoped class names and CSS Variables, then generate static CSS files at build time.  Basically, itâ€™s â€œCSS Modules-in-TypeScriptâ€ but with scoped CSS Variables + heaps more.  > ðŸš§   Please note, this is an alpha release.  ðŸ”¥   All styles generated at build time â€” just like Sass, Less, etc.  âœ¨   Minimal abstraction over standard CSS.  ðŸ¦„   Works with any front-end framework â€” or even without one.  ðŸŒ³   Locally scoped class names â€” just like CSS Modules.  ðŸš€   Locally scoped CSS Variables, @keyframes and @font-face rules.  ðŸŽ¨   High-level theme system with support for simultaneous themes. No globals!  ðŸ›    Utils for generating variable-based calc expressions.  ðŸ’ª   Type-safe styles via CSSType.  ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸   Optional runtime version for development and testing.  ðŸ™ˆ   Optional API for dynamic runtime theming.  > ðŸ–¥   Try it out for yourself in CodeSandbox.  Write your styles in .css.ts files.    ---  Want to work at a higher level while maximising style re-use? Check out ðŸ¨ Sprinkles, our official zero-runtime atomic CSS framework, built on top of vanilla-extract.  ---

sections.name: Styling API
sections.content: style  Creates styles attached to a locally scoped class name.    > ðŸ’¡ To improve maintainability, each style block can only target a single element. To enforce this, all selectors must target the & character which is a reference to the current element. For example, '&:hover:not(:active)' is considered valid, while '& > a' and ` & ${childClass}]  are not. > > If you want to target another scoped class then it should be defined within the style block of that class instead. For example,  [& ${childClass}]  is invalid since it targets ${childClass}, so it should instead be defined in the style block for childClass. > > If you want to globally target child nodes within the current element (e.g. '& > a'), you should use [globalStyle` instead.

sections.name: style
sections.content: style

sections.name: styleVariants
sections.content: Creates a collection of named style variants.

sections.name: globalStyle
sections.content: Creates styles attached to a global selector.    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createTheme
sections.content: createGlobalTheme  Creates a theme attached to a global selector, but with locally scoped variable names.    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.  ## createTheme

sections.name: createGlobalTheme
sections.content: Creates a theme attached to a global selector, but with locally scoped variable names.    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createThemeContract
sections.content: Creates a contract for themes to implement.  Ensure this function is called within a .css.ts context, otherwise variable names will be mismatched between themes.  > ðŸ’¡ This is useful if you want to split your themes into different bundles. In this case, your themes would be defined in separate files, but we'll keep this example simple.

sections.name: assignVars
sections.content: Assigns a collection of CSS Variables anywhere within a style block.  > ðŸ’¡ This is useful for creating responsive themes since it can be used within @media blocks.    > ðŸ’¡ All variables passed into this function must be assigned or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createVar
sections.content: Creates a single CSS Variable.

sections.name: fallbackVar
sections.content: Provides fallback values when consuming variables.

sections.name: fontFace
sections.content: Creates a custom font attached to a locally scoped font name.

sections.name: globalFontFace
sections.content: Creates a globally scoped custom font.

sections.name: keyframes
sections.content: Creates a locally scoped set of keyframes.

sections.name: globalKeyframes
sections.content: Creates a globally scoped set of keyframes.

sections.name: composeStyles
sections.content: Combines mutliple styles into a single class string, while also deduplicating and removing unnecessary spaces.    > ðŸ’¡ Styles can also be provided in shallow and deeply nested arrays. Think of it as a static version of classnames.

sections.name: Utility Functions
sections.content: We also provide a standalone package of optional utility functions to make it easier to work with CSS in TypeScript.  > ðŸ’¡ This package can be used with any CSS-in-JS library.

sections.name: calc
sections.content: Streamlines the creation of CSS calc expressions.

sections.name: Dynamic API
sections.content: We also provide a lightweight standalone package to support dynamic runtime theming.

sections.name: createInlineTheme
sections.content: Implements a theme contract at runtime as an inline style object.

sections.name: setElementTheme
sections.content: Implements a theme contract on an element.    > ðŸ’¡ All variables passed into this function must be assigned or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: setElementVar
sections.content: Sets a single var on an element.

sections.name: Setup
sections.content: There are currently a few integrations to choose from.

sections.name: Webpack
sections.content: Install the dependencies.

sections.name: esbuild
sections.content: Install the dependencies.   > Please note: There are currently no automatic readable class names during development. However, you can still manually provide a debug ID as the last argument to functions that generate scoped styles, e.g. export const className = style({ ... }, 'className');

sections.name: Vite
sections.content: Warning: Currently the Vite plugin doesn't rebuild files when dependent files change, e.g. updating theme.css.ts should rebuild styles.css.ts which imports theme.css.ts. This is a limitation in the Vite Plugin API that will hopefully be resolved soon. You can track the Vite issue here: https://github.com/vitejs/vite/issues/3216  1. Install the dependencies.    > Please note: There are currently no automatic readable class names during development. However, you can still manually provide a debug ID as the last argument to functions that generate scoped styles, e.g. export const className = style({ ... }, 'className');

sections.name: Gatsby
sections.content: To add to your Gatsby site, use the gatsby-plugin-vanilla-extract plugin.
